title: 110_hr7042
content: The "First Responders Support Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title. It expands disability benefits for first responders. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase benefits for first responders. The amendment includes raising the benefit amount to $350,000 and making adjustments to determine benefit amounts in accordance with subsection (h)(2). Additionally, the effective date of the amendment is changed to the date of enactment of the First Responders Support Act of 2008. The First Responders Support Act of 2008 increases benefits for disabled public safety officers who sustain catastrophic injuries in the line of duty. Benefits are determined based on the level of disability, with a minimum requirement of 50 percent disability. The Director will establish a schedule of disability levels associated with specific injuries. The First Responders Support Act of 2008 increases benefits for disabled public safety officers who sustain catastrophic injuries in the line of duty. Benefits are determined based on the level of disability, with a minimum requirement of 50 percent disability. The Director will establish a schedule of disability levels associated with specific injuries, expediting benefits for eligible claimants. The Attorney General will promulgate regulations within 9 months of the Act's enactment to carry out amendments. $3,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013 to hire employees and obtain technology for processing claims and disability determinations under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act. SEC. 3. EDUCATIONAL BENEFITS. Section 1212(a) of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide financial assistance to eligible dependents at a monthly rate of up to $1,500, based on their academic workload. Regulations will be established by the Director for determining the amount of assistance each fiscal year. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to adjust benefits annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The amendment also clarifies the amount eligible dependents receive. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to adjust benefits annually based on the Consumer Price Index. The amendment clarifies the amount eligible dependents receive and includes provisions for the child of the spouse of an officer in case of the officer's catastrophic injury or death. SEC. 4. CREDIT FOR CONTINUING CARE OF FIRST RESPONDERS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for continuing care for injured first responders. The new section allows a tax credit for qualified medical expenses paid by injured first responders or their family members, capped at $7,500 per year. The credit is reduced by 5% of adjusted gross income over $75,000 ($150,000 for joint filers). The term 'qualified injured first responder' refers to a public safety officer with an injury that significantly impairs their ability to work while on duty. 'Family member' includes those defined in section 267(c)(4). 'Qualified medical expenses' are unreimbursed medical costs related to an injury incurred while on duty as a public safety officer. The text discusses the definition of a public safety officer and states that no double benefit shall be allowed for expenses related to this section. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code to reflect these changes. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. Additionally, expanding counseling and mental health services is addressed in Section 5. In this section, the term "Director" refers to the Director of the Bureau of Justice Assistance, "eligible organization" means an organization providing free or reduced cost mental health services to public safety officers injured in the line of duty, "public safety officer" is defined as per the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, and "reduced cost" means charging not more than 50 percent of the usual amount for mental health services or counseling. The Director can grant funds to eligible organizations for mental health services for injured public safety officers and their families. Organizations must apply with required information.
